title: Will there be a new episode of mass killing in Turkey before 1 January 2017?
preds: Erdogan loves to hunt down Kurds and the Stadium bombings give him an excuse and prior to DT TAKING OFFICE would be prudent.
Down 15% due to passage of time.
Scaling down because January 1st is almost here.

Turkey, my country. I hope there will never be such a tragedy both in my country and anywhere in the world. I will be truly objective: Turkey lived an enormous unity after July 15, 2016 Failed Coup Attempt. However the politicians begin to split against the wishes of Turkish People, they couldn't keep this soul inside their policy. Turkey has lots of threats both at home and abroad. The exterior enemies are not countries but the global terrorist organizations, e. g. ISIS is a huge threat also for Turkey. PKK's been its enemies for over 30 years. FETO, led by cleric Fethullah Gulen (former-ally-then-enemy for the ruling party AKP), is also a matter of Turkish national security. But Turkey has become closer again with its former allies, Russia and Israel. If friendly and well-intended cooperation between those countries become much more strong, Turkey will continue to protect its current stable atmosphere. Yet I see an comparetively high per cent of chance for a bad incident until Christmas.

ISIS might choose turkey for attacks as they have been pushed out of Mosul. They probably try their best to respond Mosul offensive by attacks outside their territory for propaganda reason. Continuous Russian and Assad's attack on Aleppo could increase refugee flow from Syria to turkey which increases the chance of ISIS infiltration in turkey as well. However, the security will be tight as well.â€‹
Down from 5% entered on 15 September, for passage of time

Troubling new developments this past week with the arrest of members of congress belonging to the second largest opposition party, the pro-Kurdish HDP.  The government accuses the HDP of "financing and supporting an armed Kurdish insurgency." 
Erdogan has also issued "emergency decrees extending the time detainees can be held without counsel and allowing foreigners to Thebe deported without a court order." Police raided the country’s oldest independent newspaper, Cumhuriyet, and arrested two mayors of the largest majority-Kurdish province, Diyarbakir.
There were a lot of killings, injury, imprisonment, etc during coup and subsequent state of emergency - numbers didn't rise to meet definition of "mass killing"

Casualties have been sparse since the State of Emergency was declared, and most conflict attributed to Turkey appears to be happening in Syria. It seems that Russia benefits from stability in Turkey and there exists some cooperation. Also, time window for the forecast is closing.

Need to watch conditions there - operations against Kurdish areas going on recently and sounds like stepping up today.  Mayor of Diyarbakir has been detained or arrested.  Saw something yesterday about destruction of tents where IDPs living - also targeting of Kurdish area.  Still low on this forecast because untangling deaths due to violence from deaths of civilians will to be difficult.
Fair number of deaths so far. Massive instability in Syria poses spillover threat in Turkey

All branches of the services have faced President Erdogan’s retribution . Around 180 senior officers were detained, of whom 140 are said to remain in custody. In addition 149 senior commanders --- 87 Army generals, 30 Air Force generals and 32 admirals --- were dismissed along with 1.099 officers of other rank and 151 non-commissioned officers.

By the time the cease fire is broken the weather will have changed. The rain and snow will start in the next 4-8 weeks in the region.

For convenience: "We will consider a mass killing to have occurred when the deliberate actions of armed groups, including but not limited to state security forces, rebel armies, and other militias, result in the deaths of at least 1,000 noncombatant civilians targeted as part of a specific group, over a period of one year or less. A noncombatant civilian is any person who is not a current member of a formal or irregular military organization and who does not pose an immediate threat to the life, physical safety, or property of other people." Source http://www.earlywarningproject.com/definitions
Down 10% to be closer to the consensus. One reason is the presumed increased difficulty in getting news unflattering to Erdogan.
i was at 1% before the coup.
It seems certain the either the Kurds or ISIS or both will strike again.  The uncertainty is if they will strike successfully before the first of the year.
Down 5% due to passage of time and lack of mass killings.  However, still a volatile situation.
Very volatile political situation raises probabilities.
Down 5% to be closer to the consensus.
Erdogan won the election, then, following the Morsi model, has now arranged events so no additional elections are likely.    Eventually there will be mass killings but not before January 2017.

If not before Jan 1, 2017, by 2019. The variable that would change that event would be if they allowed the US and German governments more access and cooperation within their security. We have an ok working relationship with them but it could be much better. They need to learn to trust us enough to allow us access to their informants and to alert us when there is movement, especially when people with suspected ties to radical groups leave the country.

Looking at part of the EWP definitions, I’d like to offer an opinion about two points related to this phrase:

Male citizens after serving their compulsory service are obligated to be recalled up to military service until they are 46 years of age. After males are recalled up, the Turkish parliament can declare that the state is in a critical condition which makes women from ages 18 to 42 are obligated to serve. As many of us here remember - compulsory service is a great homogenizer of ethnic groups. Should the ax fall only on one or two groups it will ripple into the population of the soldiers families and create a caste system beyond rank in the services - and it looks like the Air Force could be the service to watch closest as Ozturk (the General bearing the brunt of Erdogans accusations) so this service has a greater representation in the upper class in Turkey as evidenced by their boldness, they felt it necessary to support the constitution that Erdogan is destroying, to stand up a coup attempt. A mass execution of service members would quickly become a problem on the streets.

265 deaths. Seems the magic 1000 figure can be hit this year. 
http://www.news.com.au/world/breaking-news/265-deaths-in-failed-turkey-coup/news-story/1111b2a30416fb70d83299cf505612f1

President Erdogan wants to transform Turkey to a presidential system. This necessitates changes to the constitution, which in turn requires a 3/5th majority in parliament.
When elections in June 2015 did not bring this majority, especially because the Kurdish HDP party entered parliament, Erdogan ended the peace process with the Kurdish PKK. Martial law and a media blackout in Kurdish areas followed, but reports of systematic destruction of HDP strongholds including the killing of hundreds of civilians still came to light. The repeat elections of November 2015 did not result in a 3/5th majority for Edogan, again, but the whole process demonstrates his willingness to sacrifice peace and hundreds of lives for his political aims and increased internal tensions and the societal polarization.
With Erdogans counter-coup and his Gleichschaltung of the judiciary, executive, media and education sector coupled with the removal of parliamentary immunity of more than a fourth of all parliamentarians, including 80% of the HDP representatives, Erdogan has everything in place to allow him to establish a totalitarian regime. Totalitarian regimes are historically prone to commit mass killings.
Edogans past use of force for political ends and his apparent lack of respect for human lives (for example illustrated by the debate about reintroducing the death penalty), combined his adventurism in foreign relations paint a picture of his character that makes it likely he could resort the use of deadly force against civilians on a grander scale.
As Turkey internal division between Kemalists and Islamists border on the edge of a civil war and a peaceful resolution is remote, the combined effects of Government purges and repression against opposition, the conflict with the PKK, terrorism from ISIS and civil strife between Kemalists and Islamists will most probably result in more than 1000 civilians being killed by armed forces, police or militias during this year.
Danger. Leave if you can! Why are critical F-35 components assembled here?

Note that I had originally ( a few weeks ago) a high probability on the basis of the very difficult situation in Turkey but the definition of MK is quite strict.

All Because they started before mid-night. The concept is that one lets the population wake up to occupied streets and building having passed the wee hours rounding up and arresting officials. Need to readjust as I didn't grasp the question correctly. As I understand now, mass killing here would involve for instance Kurdish population or refugees, seems unlikely that ISIS indiscriminate attacks will reach 1000 dead

While Turkey will step security at home and aide in Iraq and Syria up following the attacks last week, ISIS will undoubtedly try to send the message to the rest of the world and potential recruits that despite the losses that they face in occupied areas, they are still present and only becoming more dangerous. They have recently amped up their foreign attacks, due in large to the mounting pressure that they feel from coalition forces in Iraq and Syria and will continue with this trend of solicited attacks around the world. I do not believe that it will be a straight forward attack, but a small group of like minded individuals (2-3); perhaps an independent group that pledges allegiance to the group. I also believe that there will be a string of suicide bombings in Istanbul and other Turkish towns.

As far as I can discern, blowing up random people at an airport does not meet the question's criterion, which requires the victims to be targeted as members of some specific group.  I don't like tourists any better than you do (if it's tourist season, why can't you shoot them?) but they seem ill-suited as a category for "mass killing" in this context.

President Erdogan is running a highly destabilising 'soft' Islamisation program. This is proving to be unpopular with the urban educated elite & with members of the security forces, long considered the bastion of Turkish secularism. This unhealthy relationship between shadowy 'Turkish agents' and IS may give President Erdogan the idea of using IS fighters as proxies within Turkey to attack 'soft targets', then blaming these attacks on Kurdish militants, justifying the Turkish government's intransigent & bloody crack down on restive Kurdish areas.

However, Turkish officials likely are prepared for this probability, so such an act may not be easy to conduct in the following year.

Per Google results for "Turkey, bombings, 2015", then same for 2016, there were 4 bombings in 2015, then 7 in the first 6 months of 2016. The EWP defines "mass killing" as killing at least 1,000 civilians. So far the attacks have resulted in far too small numbers to suggest a significant number of future true mass attacks, but with so many perpetrator groups, there is some possibility of at least one real mass attack at some future time.

It depends how we classify "mass-killing."  If we're talking about a bombing or other terrorist attack in a major Turkish city that kills dozens or hundreds of people, I think the chances are unfortunately considerable.  If we're talking about an organized massacre by either Turkish or militant (Kurdish, ISIS, whoever) forces, I think the chances are lower, but non-trivial.  There is also a possibility that there are mass protests somewhere in Turkey, and large numbers of protestors are killed by government crackdown, as has happened several times in Egypt in the past 5 years.

@Milosz and @dowser both made an excellent point about the deaths of kurds being counted or not. The USA/EU classify them as a terrorist group, but at least 50% of these deaths are clearly civilian. Can we get official word, please on how Good Judgement counts Kurds? If they are counted, then the chances of exceeding 1000 deaths this year is over 90%, if not 10%.
(no change) @EarlyWarningProject Here are two specific issues that I do not think this question addresses:

There is an even chance that Kurd or ISIS or government action will trigger or result in more mass killings.   The weapons are available and the mentality exists which in combo certainly creates the ambient necessary for such an event.
The statistical risk assessment suggests a 1% chance (http://www.earlywarningproject.com/risk_assessments).  Accordingly, I'm starting with a low estimate.

bombe bombe i još bombi
sukob sa kurdima  sukob sa rusima
biće veselo na prostoru turske
